conclusion: To determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point, we need to analyze the motion described by the graph. The graph shows the acceleration \(a\) as a function of time \(t\).
The particle starts from rest, so the initial velocity \(v(0) = 0\).
From \(0\) to \(\frac{t_0}{2}\): The acceleration increases linearly from \(0\) to \(a_0\).
From \(\frac{t_0}{2}\) to \(t_0\): The acceleration decreases linearly from \(a_0\) to \(0\).
From \(t_0\) to \(\frac{3t_0}{2}\): The acceleration decreases linearly from \(0\) to \(-a_0\).
From \(\frac{3t_0}{2}\) to \(2t_0\): The acceleration increases linearly from \(-a_0\) to \(0\).

premise: The velocity \(v(t)\) is the integral of the acceleration \(a(t)\).
The velocity \(v(t)\) is the integral of the acceleration \(a(t)\).
The velocity \(v(t)\) is the integral of the acceleration \(a(t)\).
The velocity \(v(t)\) is the integral of the acceleration \(a(t)\).
The position \(x(t)\) is the integral of the velocity \(v(t)\).
The position \(x(t)\) is the integral of the velocity \(v(t)\).
